factoid: Márya Dmítrievna admonished Natásha for some time.
Márya Dmítrievna enjoined Natásha that it must all be kept from her father.
Márya Dmítrievna assured Natásha that nobody would know anything about it if Natásha would undertake to forget it all.
Márya Dmítrievna assured Natásha that nobody would know anything about it if Natásha would not let anyone see that something had happened.
Natásha did not reply to Márya Dmítrievna.
Natásha did not sob any longer.
Natásha grew cold.
Natásha had a shivering fit.
Márya Dmítrievna put a pillow under Natásha's head.
Márya Dmítrievna covered Natásha with two quilts.
Márya Dmítrievna brought Natásha some lime‑flower water.
Natásha did not respond to Márya Dmítrievna.
Márya Dmítrievna told Natásha to sleep.
Márya Dmítrievna went out of the room supposing Natásha to be asleep.
Natásha was not asleep.
Natásha had a pale face.
Natásha had fixed wide‑open eyes.
Natásha looked straight before herself.
Natásha did not sleep that night.
Natásha did not weep that night.
Natásha did not speak to Sónya that night.
Sónya got up and went to Natásha several times that night.
Count Rostóv returned from his estate near Moscow next day.
Count Rostóv returned in time for lunch.
Count Rostóv had promised to return.
Count Rostóv was in very good spirits.
The affair with the purchaser was going on satisfactorily.
There was nothing to keep Count Rostóv in Moscow any longer.
Count Rostóv missed the countess.
Márya Dmítrievna met Count Rostóv.
Márya Dmítrievna told Count Rostóv that Natásha had been very unwell the day before.
Márya Dmítrievna told Count Rostóv that they had sent for the doctor.
Márya Dmítrievna told Count Rostóv that Natásha was better now.
Natásha had not left her room that morning.
Natásha had compressed and parched lips.
Natásha had dry fixed eyes.
Natásha sat at the window that morning.
Natásha uneasily watched the people who drove past.
Natásha hurriedly glanced round at anyone who entered the room.
Natásha was evidently expecting news of Count Rostóv.
Natásha expected that Count Rostóv would come.
Natásha expected that Count Rostóv would write to her.
Count Rostóv came to see Natásha.
Natásha turned anxiously round at the sound of a man's footstep.
Natásha's face resumed its cold and malevolent expression.
Natásha did not get up to greet Count Rostóv.
Count Rostóv asked Natásha “What is the matter with you, my angel? Are you ill?”
Natásha answered Count Rostóv “Yes, ill.”
Natásha assured Count Rostóv that nothing had happened.
Natásha asked Count Rostóv not to worry.
Márya Dmítrievna confirmed Natásha's assurances that nothing had happened.
The count saw clearly that something had gone wrong during his absence.
The count was so terrible for him to think that anything disgraceful had happened to his beloved daughter.
The count prized his own cheerful tranquillity.
The count avoided inquiries.
The count tried to assure himself that nothing particularly had happened.
The count was dissatisfied that Natásha's indisposition delayed their return to the country.
Pierre had been intending to go away somewhere from his wife.
Pierre did not want to be near his wife.
The Rostóvs came to Moscow soon after Pierre had intended to go away.
Natásha had an effect on Pierre that made him hasten to carry out his intention.
Pierre went to Tver to see Joseph Alexéevich’s widow.
Joseph Alexéevich’s widow had long since promised to hand over to Pierre some papers of her deceased husband’s.
Pierre returned to Moscow.
Pierre was handed a letter from Márya Dmítrievna.
The letter asked Pierre to come and see Márya Dmítrievna on a matter of great importance relating to Andrew Bolkónski and his betrothed.
Pierre had been avoiding Natásha.
Pierre felt that his feeling for Natásha was stronger than a married man’s should be for his friend’s fiancée.
Fate constantly threw Pierre and Natásha together.
Pierre wondered what could have happened.
Pierre wondered what they wanted with him.
Pierre wondered if Prince Andrew would hurry up and marry Natásha.
A familiar voice called to Pierre on the Tverskóy Boulevard.
Someone shouted “Pierre! Been back long?” to Pierre.
Pierre raised his head.
A sleigh was drawn by two gray trotting-horses.
The sleigh was bespattering the dashboard with snow.
Anatole and Makárin dashed past Pierre.
Anatole was sitting upright in the classic pose of military dandies.
Anatole's lower face was hidden by his beaver collar.
Anatole's head was slightly bent.
Anatole's face was fresh and rosy.
Anatole wore a white‑plumed hat tilted to one side.
Anatole's hair was curled and pomaded.
Anatole's hair was besprinkled with powdery snow.
